citation.article-title: Micromonospora marina sp. nov., isolated from sea sand
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Micromonospora marina sp. nov.
Micromonospora marina (ma. ri′ na. L. fem. adj. marina of the sea, marine, pertaining to sea sand, the source from which the type strain was isolated).
Aerobic, Gram-positive, mesophilic actinomycete that forms a well-developed and extensively branched substrate mycelium.
No aerial mycelium is produced.
The vegetative mycelium on ISP 2 is brownish orange, turning to brownish black upon sporulation.
A pale yellow diffusible pigment is produced on ISP 2 and a pale brown to brown pigment on ISP 7.
Spores are spherical to oval, appear to be smooth and are non-motile.
Nitrate reduction is negative.
Starch hydrolysis, gelatin liquefaction and milk peptonization are positive.
Decomposes l-tyrosine, but not adenine, hypoxanthine or xanthine.

Utilizes l-arabinose, d-fructose, d-galactose, d-glucose, glycerol (weakly), d-mannitol (weakly), melibiose, raffinose, d-ribose and d-xylose, but not lactose, l-rhamnose or salicin as sole carbon sources for energy.
The optimal temperature for growth is 25–30 °C.
Grows at 15–45 °C, at pH 5 to 9, and in the presence of 7 % NaCl.
The cell wall peptidoglycan contains glutamic acid, alanine and meso-diaminopimelic acid.
The acyl type of the cell wall is glycolyl.
The predominant menaquinones are MK-10(H4) and MK-10(H6).
Major cellular fatty acids are iso-C15 : 0 and iso-C16 : 0.
The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 72.0 mol%.
Habitat is sea sand.
The type strain is JSM1-1T (=JCM 12870T =PCU 269 T =TISTR 1566T), isolated from sea sand in Thailand.
